hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, holding up. Just keeping to myself these days.
Still finding time for my photography, mostly at home.
Street’s a bit different now, harder to get shots.
Trying not to attract attention, you know?
I'm coping. Been sticking with my photography, nothing too risky.
Used to shoot a lot on the streets, but it’s tense now.
Saw things last week that made me stay clear for a bit.
Gotta be careful where you point a lens lately.
Everyone’s watching everyone else.
I’m alright. Still doing analog street photography, despite the hassle.
Snapped some strange scenes this weekend—felt like the city was shifting.
Lots of new faces moving around, handing out parcels.
I keep my gear light, quick to stash if needed.
Film’s hard to come by, but worth it for real moments.
After all, sometimes a photo tells more than a report can.
I'm hanging in. Photography keeps me grounded. I use 35mm film, old style.
Last Saturday, caught the so-called invisible citizens helping out in Block 7.
No badges, just people delivering supplies behind the Council’s narrative.
I burn through film faster now, never sure what I’ll catch.
It’s riskier than before—wrong street, wrong shot, could tank my BCI.
But that’s the point—images last beyond headlines or stats.
I keep the best rolls hidden off the grid.
Barely holding up, honestly. Photography’s my sanity, using smuggled 35mm film—digital doesn’t cut it.
My dad was BCI, so I grew up watching what stories get erased.
Lately, the city’s upside down. I shot a whole roll on the 'vanished' as they resurfaced.
They weren’t hiding—openly moving supplies, almost daring cameras to notice.
Council says order’s back, but my film shows otherwise—history happening in places the system won’t see.
If I get caught, it explains my BCI drop. Worth the risk for the truth.
I’ve got negatives locked up in three separate spots. Paranoid, maybe, but it’s habit now.
Guess this is the real underground—catching what the city tries to forget.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still shooting analog.
Film’s harder to get with all this disruption lately.
I stick to quiet streets now, keep to myself.
Crowds are unpredictable. Not worth the risk anymore.
Haven’t developed my latest roll yet.
That’s right, analog photography.
Supply drops make old routes unreliable for shots.
Too many new faces on the streets after Halden’s death.
Missed some opportunities with the assemblies—had to play it safe.
Holding back on developing until things feel stable.
Hard to know who’s watching lately.
Analog photography, Alex. Some rituals stay.
Cameras don’t lie, even when everything else does.
Night shots have changed—more ‘invisible’ people in the open now.
Whole neighborhoods feel less policed, more alive, but tense.
Caught some of them supplying goods in locked zones.
The film stash is running low since supply lines changed.
Makes every frame riskier, and somehow, more honest.
You got it, analog film. My quiet fight.
These days, catching raw moments is trickier—the city’s in flux.
With the BCI acting up, more disappeared folks in my frame.
Last week, I shot a supply handoff right near the tram yard.
Used to be invisible, now out there in daylight, like new rules.
Made me rethink who’s really in control—certain faces, suddenly proud.
It’s the most unpredictable the city’s felt since I started.
I’m almost out of developer, but can’t stop—something real is showing.
Analog photography—only way I trust what’s real, even now.
My dad taught me the old light meter trick before BCI days.
Everything changed after Halden—BCI glitches made the missing reappear.
I trailed one group supplying a whole block, camera hidden under my coat.
No patrols even blinked—they seemed confused, or chose to look away.
A woman caught me framing her and actually smiled at the lens.
Every roll I shoot now feels like evidence—like history sneaking in.
I make backup prints, analog only—nothing digital leaves home.
Feels risky, sure. But when reality’s up for grabs, this is my side.
